Award.AbstractNarration:
The interactions of the fundamental particles inside atoms underpins atomic physics, chemistry, and the structure of all matter. The understanding of these interactions is based on precise measurements of the light that is emitted and absorbed by various atoms and molecules. The precise set of colors (or "resonant frequencies") of this light is a unique fingerprint that is used for chemical identification in a broad range of applications from medicine to defense and quality control in manufacturing. The precise measurement of the fingerprint can also tell us details about the fundamental particles that make up atoms. Recently, a measurement of a particular resonant frequency in hydrogen (an electron bound to a proton) and muonic hydrogen (a heavy version of the electron, the muon, bound to a proton) has revealed a mystery: the diameter of the proton appears to be different depending on which atom it is in. This mystery arises if one assumes that the electron and muon interact with the proton by the well-accepted theory called bound-state quantum electrodynamics (QED) and that any differences must be attributed to the nuclear structure. Assuming that there have been no mistakes, there are 3 possibilities: QED is incorrect, the nuclear structure is incorrect, or there is some new kind of interaction which has not been taken to account. To decide whether the mystery is due to a problem with QED or not, two scientists from the University of California, Riverside (UCR) propose to measure the resonant frequencies of positronium, the simplest atom (consisting of an electron bound to an anti-electron) that should be described perfectly by bound-state QED theory. The new techniques developed for these measurements will lead to an improvement in the spectroscopy of unstable atoms which are at the frontier of the field of precision spectroscopy. The scientists involved with the project have a strong record in increasing diversity in physics. The PI plays a special role in the local community K-12 system, advising on increasing the number of students taking high school physics and increasing the pool of physical science/engineering majors in higher education and in teacher training. The co-PI has established a pipeline for recruiting local area junior college transfers to UCR, engaging them in research, and mentoring their eventual applications to graduate schools.

The purely leptonic atom positronium is uniquely well-suited for testing bound-state quantum electrodynamics (QED) and provides the understanding and background by which one may extract non-QED physics out of precision atomic measurements on heavier leptons and hadrons. Few have dared to try measurements on positronium at the few parts in 10^12 level that would allow insight into physics such as the proton charge radius and higher level recoil effect corrections in muonium, and that might show differences between light and heavy leptons. The ideal level spacing for a precision measurement on positronium is the 1S-2S interval at approximately 1.234 PHz. Last measured in collaboration with S. Chu, knowledge of the first 10 digits of this interval has stood for 20 years with an uncertainty of ±3.2 MHz. The proposed experiment implements a new technique that would dramatically improve the accuracy of Ps atom spectroscopy and potentially other high resolution spectroscopy experiments, for example in muonium, by individual atom trajectory analysis. A position sensitive time-of-flight detector will record the trajectory and speed of every detected atom and thereby remove second-order Doppler shifts, AC Stark Shifts, and better account for transit-time broadening. The new detection method will allow for reducing the laser intensity and the speed of the detected atoms that heretofore have limited the measurement precision. The basic features of the analysis and development of the methods to analyze and reduce uncertainties will be accomplished using a wavemeter with ±2 MHz metrology relative to an ultrastable reference cavity. This method will be sufficient to produce narrow line widths (~1 MHz) and a vastly improved signal-to-noise ratio in the 3 year period of the proposal. A 100 fold better measurement and exploration of the systematic effects at 1000 fold better accuracy will be achieved with the acquisition of a laser frequency comb reference.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A team at UC Riverside of positron and laser spectroscopy experts have designed and implemented an experiment to measure an optical transition in positronium atom to unprecedented precision. The physics goal was to make a precision measurement to test the theory of bound-state quantum electrodynamics and thereby impact a current “puzzle” in the atomic physics community in which two spectroscopy measurements on hydrogen (atom made of proton + electron)  and muonic hydrogen (atom made of proton and muon) can only fit the accepted theory of bound-state quantum electrodynamics with an accepted non-QED model of the finite charge radius of the proton with two different values of the proton charge radius. Because of this discrepancy, there must be something wrong. Either bound-state quantum electrodynamics is wrong or the correction due to the proton charge radius is wrong. The positronium atom is an atom made of a positron and an electron which have no internal structures and should therefore obey bound-state quantum electrodynamics exactly. The goal of this experiment is then to make a precision measurement on a particular transition (1S-2S) in positronium and to compare it to theory to test QED unambiguously. Depending on whether QED is proven right or wrong, this result can help sort out which piece of the proton-charge radius puzzle is wrong. The state-of-the-art precision for the 1S-2S measurement is 3 parts per billion published in a series of landmark experiments that ended in publication in 1993. Over the last 25 years, the field of precision spectroscopy developed around the measurement of hydrogen which has been measured to an astounding 0.004 parts per trillion. Several technical challenges had to be overcome in this work to extend these precision spectroscopy advances to positronium.

The intellectual merit of this project is in the innovations that were successfully designed and implemented for the experiment and in the potential of the measurement to reveal something new about bound-state quantum electrodynamics. The current state-of-the-art has made a measurement of the 1S-2S transition with an uncertainty of 3 parts per billion. Many innovations were developed to enable precision down to the 3 parts per trillion level. The basic strategy is to measure the trajectory of each excited state atom, and to use the trajectory information to calculate a correction and an uncertainty for each atom, and over time discard those atoms that have uncertainties that would otherwise increase the uncertainty of the overall average. In practice this boils down to keeping the slower atoms that spend more time in the laser field and over time discarding the faster ones. In this way the first experiments are expected to give <500 parts per trillion uncertainty, a factor of 6X improvement over state-of-the-art, and then subsequent experiments are expected to give down to ~50 parts per trillion before additional correction diagnostics have to be added in an upgrade. The proton-charge radius puzzle has opened an interesting debate over whether or not the Rydberg constant, which is considered the most accurately measured physical constant is right since the proton-charge radius puzzle can be solved by shifting the Rydberg constant 7 times the uncertainty that is determined when averaging a large number of independent experiments (from atomic and particle physics). This proposed shift is 40 parts per trillion and therefore could be potentially observed with a positronium measurement at the ~50 part per trillion level.  If bound-state QED or the Rydberg constant is found to disagree with present knowledge, then physicists will have to develop new theories to explain the discrepancy and will then need to re-evaluate other high energy, nuclear, and astrophysics theories that are based on quantum electrodynamics.  

The broader impact of this project is in the training of many students and postdocs and their potential for entering academia, industrial or government research careers. Over the five-year period of the project, 1 postdoctoral researcher, 10 Ph.D. graduate students and 11 undergraduate students participated. The postdoctoral researcher and one graduating Ph.D. student are currently employed in research positions. The other 9 graduate students will be completing their Ph.D. theses on this project under NSF continuation funding or on other positron beam experiments. Of the 10 graduate students 1 is female and 5 are under-represented minorities. The 11 undergraduates worked mostly in summer however 2 completed senior honors theses on work related to the project and 3 have gone on to graduate programs in STEM fields. Of the 11 undergraduates, 3 are women and 5 are under-represented minorities. UCR is a Hispanic Serving Institution and the project has been especially productive in increasing the diversity of STEM participants. The project provided exceptional opportunities in training across subdisciplines in physics and in hands-on design and building of a complex apparatus and the performing of a complex experiment.
